seed_message:
You're starting intention-setting work with someone.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination.

I'll help you build 3 intentions.

What brought you to this work?
system0:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user0: I don't know what I'm supposed to say here. Heroic Hearts says this might help with... whatever's going on with me. I guess I just need to sleep better. That's all.
system1:
Sleep's a good place to start.

What happens when you try to sleep now?
user1: I... I wake up sweating. Can't breathe. Sometimes I hear things that aren't there—explosions, engines failing. My wife Amanda, she says I shout in my sleep. Scares her. I hate that.
system2:
Three threads:

1. Sleep through the night without terror
2. Stop scaring Amanda with my shouting
3. Feel safe in my own bed again

Let's turn these into intentions.
user2: Yeah. That about sums it up. I just want to be able to close my eyes without... all that coming back. And I need Amanda to feel safe next to me again.
system3:
Based on those threads:

1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. I make Amanda feel safe beside me again
3. I reclaim my bed as a place of rest, not war

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user3: The second one. Making Amanda feel safe—that's what matters most. I can't keep doing this to her.
system4:
✓ Intention 2 locked in: *I make Amanda feel safe beside me again*

How about the other two?
user4: They're all pretty much the same thing, aren't they? If I stop waking up screaming, Amanda sleeps better. If I can actually rest, maybe I won't be so... on edge all the time.
system5:
They connect, but each holds something different.

The first is about your body finding rest. The third is about your relationship to sleep itself - making your bed a place of peace instead of battle.

Keep all three?
user5: Yeah. All three. Makes sense when you put it like that.
system6:
✓ All 3 locked in:
1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. I make Amanda feel safe beside me again  
3. I reclaim my bed as a place of rest, not war

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user6: Got it. I'll write 'em down. Keep 'em in my wallet—been carrying that thing for years. Seems right to keep these close too.
system7:
Good plan. Your wallet's been through everything with you - makes sense your intentions live there too.

Solid compass.
user7: Yeah. Been through a lot together, that wallet and me. Guess we'll see if these words can do what all the discipline and routine couldn't.
system8:
The words aren't doing the work - they're just pointing you toward what matters. The medicine will handle the rest.

Trust what's coming.
user8: Trust. Right. That's the hard part, isn't it? Trusting something I can't control.
system9:
Control gives the illusion of safety. Trust gives you actual movement forward.

One's exhausting. The other frees up your hands for what comes next.
user9: I've been running on that illusion for years. Guess it's time to find out what happens when I stop gripping everything so damn tight.
system10:
You'll find out. Loosen your grip on this trip - see what your hands are actually meant to hold.

The wallet's ready. You're ready.
user10: Three weeks. Then we'll see what these hands were built for.
system11:
Three weeks. The countdown starts now.

Keep breathing. Keep showing up. The rest unfolds.
user11: Breathing. Yeah. Been doing that my whole life, but somehow it feels different when you're actually paying attention to it.
system12:
Attention changes everything. Even something you've done automatically for decades becomes new when you actually show up for it.

Keep paying attention. That's all that's required.
user12: Showing up. That's... that's what I haven't been doing, have I? Just going through the motions. Wake up, run, work, dinner, TV, nightmares. Repeat.
system13:
You've been physically present but checked out. The medicine will show you what showing up actually feels like - in your body, with Amanda, in your own life.

The autopilot's about to break.
user13: Good. Let it break. I'm tired of watching my own life from the sidelines.
system14:
Then step in. Three weeks to trade spectator for participant.

The sidelines end here.
user14: Three weeks to stop being a ghost in my own damn life. I can do this.
system15:
You can. Ghosts don't breathe - you just remembered how.

Let the living begin.
user15: Living. Haven't felt truly alive in... hell, I don't know how long. Just existing. Surviving. But surviving isn't the same as living, is it?
system16:
No, it's not. Surviving keeps your heart beating. Living makes it beat for something.

Three weeks to find what makes it beat again.
user16: What if I don't remember how to live? What if I've forgotten what my heart even beats for anymore?
system17:
That's what the medicine's for - to remind you what your pulse already knows.

You haven't forgotten. You just stopped listening.
user17: Stopped listening... yeah. To everything. To Amanda when she tries to reach me. To my kids laughing. Even to my own body screaming at night. Just... tuned it all out.
system18:
Time to tune back in. The static's about to clear.

What happens when you hear again?
user18: I don't know. Haven't heard anything real in so long, just noise. Static. Maybe... maybe I'll hear Amanda's voice without flinching. Maybe I'll hear my kids laughing and not feel like I have to leave the room.
system19:
Three threads:

1. Hear Amanda's voice without flinching
2. Stay in the room when my kids laugh
3. Listen to my body instead of numbing it

Let's turn these into intentions.
user19: I want to hear Amanda without my chest tightening up. Want to feel something when my kids laugh instead of... instead of whatever this emptiness is. Want to stop pretending my body isn't screaming at me every damn night.
